message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the painful tongue lesion and the knot-like swellings on the left temple, are consistent with giant cell arteritis. The laboratory findings showing elevated ESR further supports this diagnosis. The next best step in management would be to initiate high-dose systemic corticosteroids to prevent potential blindness, facial paralysis, or aortic aneurysm. CT or lysis therapy are not appropriate for the management of this condition. Paracetamol may provide some pain relief but does not address the underlying condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest giant cell arteritis. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the standard of care for giant cell arteritis. CT may be useful if there is suspicion of complications such as intracranial hemorrhage but it is not the next best step in management. Lysis therapy is not indicated for this condition. Paracetamol may provide some relief for the pain but is not the next best step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, history, and physical exam findings are suggestive of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA). The laboratory findings also support this diagnosis, as the Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) is elevated. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for GCA, and should be initiated urgently to prevent irreversible visual loss. CT and lysis therapy are not appropriate for the management of GCA, and paracetamol may provide some pain relief but does not address the underlying disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest temporal arteritis, and laboratory findings show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, indicative of inflammation. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the treatment of choice for temporal arteritis. CT is not necessary at this point, lysis therapy is not indicated, and paracetamol alone will not be sufficient for pain relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis. The next best step in management is high-dose systemic corticosteroids, which are considered the first-line treatment for this condition. CT and lysis therapy are not indicated in this case, and paracetamol alone is unlikely to provide sufficient pain relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given symptoms and laboratory findings suggest that the patient has giant cell arteritis. The excruciating tongue lesion and intermittent headache are typical symptoms of this condition. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis. CT is not necessary for diagnosis and lysis therapy is not an appropriate treatment for this condition. Paracetamol may provide some pain relief, but it is not a treatment for giant cell arteritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Giant Cell Arteritis. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the standard of care for this condition, so this is the next best step in the management of the patient. CT or lysis therapy is not indicated for the management of Giant Cell Arteritis. Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is a pain reliever and would not address the underlying condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest giant cell arteritis. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first line of treatment for this condition. CT and lysis therapy are not typically indicated. Paracetamol may provide some pain relief but does not treat the underlying cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, multiple knot-like swellings on the left temple, and laboratory findings suggest giant cell arteritis. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis. CT is not necessary in the management of this patient. Lysis therapy is not used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis. Paracetamol, also known as acetaminophen, can be used for pain relief but is not the next best step in management.

The exhibit shows a tongue lesion that is an indication of oral involvement. High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for Giant cell arteritis. CT or lysis therapy are not indicated for this condition. Paracetamol may provide pain relief but does not treat the underlying inflammation.
